content.webTitle: TV tonight: harrowing stories from America’s death row

fields.headline: TV tonight: harrowing stories from America’s death row
fields.bodyText: In the Executioner’s Shadow 9pm, PBS America With 30 states in the US still using the death penalty, this chilling documentary presents three death row narratives: the testimony of a former executioner who almost executed an innocent person; a survivor of the 2013 Boston marathon terrorist attack; and a victim’s parents attempting to save their daughter’s killer from death. With an increasingly privatised prison system to reckon with, the film questions what place capital punishment still has in our society. Ammar Kalia The World’s Most Scenic Railway Journeys 8pm, Channel 5 Bill Nighy narrates a 600-mile journey across northern Spain, aboard the luxurious El Transcantábrico. It’s torturous to be able to see the grilled sardines of Candás yet not be able to taste them. Still, as advertised, the scenery as seen through the carriage windows is spectacular and the company is not bad either. Ellen E Jones The Name of the Rose 9pm, BBC Two The atmospheric but glacial monastic murder mystery continues. Tonight, John Turturro’s William gives the last rites to Berengar and begins the painstaking business of determining the cause of death. In the meantime, the monastery is preparing to receive a papal envoy. Phil Harrison The Team 9pm, More4 The Danish thriller returns for a second season, this time focusing on an international European investigation following a brutal shooting at a Danish B&B that left seven dead and only one survivor. With many of the deceased illegal immigrants, the titular team get to work trying to solve a potential hate crime. A multilingual caper. AK Temple 9pm, Sky One It’s the series finale for the medical thriller and, as we have been made keenly aware, sometimes you just have to bite the bullet and team up to face the common foe. That’s the scenario for Daniel, Lee and Anna who, despite their ruined personal relationships, are obliged to join forces when Keith and Mercy track them down. Ali Catterall Get Rich Or Try Dying: Music’s Mega Legacies 9.30pm, BBC Four As hologram tours keep dead artists playing, this incisive documentary looks at the gargantuan music legacy industry, which continues to line the pockets of the estates of stars such as Elvis Presley, Bob Marley and the Doors. A peek behind the curtain at the corporations driving the music. AK Film choice Half of a Yellow Sun 12.10am, BBC Two Heartfelt adaptation of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s novel, set during the 60s Biafran war. Chiwetel Ejiofor’s professor Odenigbo and Thandie Newton as his partner Olanna are impressive leads, even when marrying post-imperial conflict with the couple’s domestic trials proves awkward for director Biyi Bandele. Paul Howlett Live sport World Cup Rugby Union 8.30am, ITV. The third place play-off. Premiership Rugby Union: Northampton Saints v Harlequins 7pm, BT Sport 1. The Saints aim to back up last week’s away win at Saracens. Championship Football: Barnsley v Bristol City 7pm, Sky Sports Main Event. A second-tier match at Oakwell.
